parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on evidence from fishery closure studies, long-term and temporary fishery closures show markedly different effects on marine fish abundance.
[Statement 2]: Long-term fishery closures demonstrated more positive outcomes for marine fish abundance.
[Statement 3]: Two site comparison studies found a higher abundance of fish species in areas closed to groundfish fisheries for six to eight years compared to open areas.
[Statement 4]: One study found more young salmon returning to rivers in the five years after the long-term closure of a commercial coastal fishery.
[Statement 5]: Temporary fishery closures showed limited or no positive effects on fish abundance.
[Statement 6]: One study in the Atlantic Ocean found no increase in the biomass of the spawning stock of cod following a temporary fishery closure compared to fished areas over nine years.
[Statement 7]: A study in the Atlantic Ocean found no change in cod catches following a temporary fishery closure when compared to fished areas.
[Statement 8]: The evidence suggests that long-term closures can lead to increased fish abundance and biomass in protected areas.
[Statement 9]: The evidence suggests that temporary closures may not provide sufficient time for fish populations to recover and show measurable increases in abundance.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__How do long-term and temporary fishery closures compare in their effects on marine fish abundance?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Marine Protected Areas that prohibit most or all fishing show significant positive effects on fish abundance and diversity based on extensive research evidence.
[Statement 2]: Thirty of 54 site comparison studies found that marine protected areas prohibiting all fishing for up to 25 years or more had higher abundances of all fish, fishery targeted fish species, and non-fishery targeted fish species compared to unprotected fished areas.
[Statement 3]: Five of six reviews across the world found that non-fished marine reserves with one to 27 years of protection had higher abundances of all fish compared to fished areas.
[Statement 4]: Five of six reviews across the world found that non-fished marine reserves with one to 27 years of protection had higher abundances of all fish and invertebrates combined compared to fished areas.
[Statement 5]: Two systematic reviews found that marine protected areas prohibiting all fishing had greater overall invertebrate abundance and biomass compared to fished areas.
[Statement 6]: Fourteen of 20 site comparison studies found that marine protected areas that had prohibited all fishing for between one to more than 25 years had higher fish species richness compared to fished areas.
[Statement 7]: Six studies found similar fish species richness between one and 20 years after all fishing was banned in protected areas compared to fished areas.
[Statement 8]: One systematic review found no difference in species richness between unfished protected areas and fished areas.
[Statement 9]: One study found a higher number of fish species in the no-fishing/no access zone of a multi-zoned marine protected area compared to partially fished zones and unprotected fished areas 10 to 15 years after implementation.
[Statement 10]: Research shows that fish in protected areas are larger than fish in fished areas.
[Statement 11]: Two global review studies and two systematic reviews found that prohibiting all fishing in marine protected areas for one to 27 years resulted in larger fish overall compared to fished areas.
[Statement 12]: Eight of 11 site comparison studies found that non-fished protected areas had larger fish overall compared to fished areas, after one to 22 years.
[Statement 13]: Eight of 11 site comparison studies found that non-fished protected areas had larger individuals of all or most fish species/groups monitored compared to fished areas, after one to 22 years.
[Statement 14]: Changes in fish community composition were observed in protected areas.
[Statement 15]: Seven site comparison studies found that protected areas where all fishing had been prohibited for between three and 16 years had different fish community composition compared to fished areas.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the observed effects on fish abundance and diversity from prohibiting most or all fishing within Marine Protected Areas?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several gear modifications beyond hook type changes can reduce unwanted catches of sharks and rays.
[Statement 2]: Increasing the lead weight on mid-water longlines to increase the sinking rate can reduce catches of unwanted sharks and rays compared to standard longlines.
[Statement 3]: Using nylon instead of wire hook attachments can reduce catches of unwanted sharks and rays compared to standard longlines.
[Statement 4]: Fishing gear fitted with electropositive deterrent materials can catch fewer unwanted sharks and rays, and fewer undersized halibut, compared to standard fishing gear or gears with non-deterrent materials.
[Statement 5]: Size-sorting escape grids fitted to prawn or shrimp trawl nets reduce unwanted fish catches by allowing the escape of unwanted sharks and other fish species.
[Statement 6]: Trawl nets fitted with both a size-sorting escape grid and a large supported escape opening reduce catches of unwanted sharks and rays compared to standard trawl nets.
[Statement 7]: Bottom trawl nets fitted with square mesh escape panels and size-sorting grids reduce the unwanted catch of sharks and stingrays compared to standard unmodified trawl nets.
[Statement 8]: Diamond mesh trawl nets with either a top square mesh escape panel or a large supported opening reduce unwanted shark catches compared to standard trawl nets.
[Statement 9]: The use of a top square mesh escape panel or a large supported opening in diamond mesh trawl nets was not effective for reducing catches of rays and sawfish.
[Statement 10]: Rigid escape windows fitted to trawl nets can reduce unwanted flatfish catches.
[Statement 11]: LED lights fitted to fishing lines on shrimp trawl nets reduce catches of unwanted fish compared to conventional trawls.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Besides changing hook type in longline fisheries, what other gear modifications can reduce unwanted catches of sharks and rays?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several gear modifications are available to reduce unwanted catch of cod and haddock in the North Sea.
[Statement 2]: Separator trawls have been found to be effective at reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 3]: One study in the North Sea showed that a separator trawl separated unwanted cod from target fish species into the lower codend.
[Statement 4]: A larger mesh size in the lower codend of a separator trawl allowed more unwanted smaller cod to escape capture.
[Statement 5]: Topless or coverless trawls showed mixed results in North Sea studies for reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 6]: One study found that topless trawls reduced unwanted catches of larger haddock but not smaller haddock.
[Statement 7]: The same study found that topless trawls reduced unwanted catches of larger Atlantic cod in only one of two cases compared to standard trawl types.
[Statement 8]: Size-sorting escape grids, which can be rigid or flexible, have proven effective at reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 9]: Eleven of fourteen replicated studies found that fitting size-sorting escape grids to fish trawl nets reduced catches of unwanted sizes of cod and other non-target fish.
[Statement 10]: Two of three replicated studies in the North Sea and Norwegian Sea found that size-sorting escape grids fitted to trawl nets improved the size-selection of haddock.
[Statement 11]: These studies found that size-sorting escape grids did not improve the size-selection of cod, compared to standard nets without grids.
[Statement 12]: Mesh escape panels or windows fitted to trawl nets showed effectiveness in North Sea studies.
[Statement 13]: Fourteen of nineteen replicated studies found that square mesh escape panels or windows fitted to diamond mesh trawl nets reduced unwanted catches of all fish species monitored.
[Statement 14]: Using square mesh codends instead of diamond mesh codends has also proved beneficial.
[Statement 15]: Three replicated studies found that trawl nets with an escape grid and a square mesh codend caught fewer unwanted cod and haddock compared to a diamond mesh codend with no grid.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of cod and haddock in the North Sea?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Mesh escape panels, size-sorting grids, and large supported openings show different levels of effectiveness for improving size-selectivity in trawl nets.
[Statement 2]: Studies on mesh escape panels show mixed results for size-selectivity improvement.
[Statement 3]: Some studies found that modifying the position and/or size of mesh escape panels improved the size-selectivity of haddock and whiting.
[Statement 4]: Other studies found that size-selectivity for cod was similar when using mesh escape panels compared to standard trawls.
[Statement 5]: One study found that when mesh escape panels were combined with size-sorting grids, the size-selectivity of whiting was increased compared to standard nets.
[Statement 6]: Size-sorting grids demonstrate more consistent effectiveness for improving size-selectivity.
[Statement 7]: Some studies found that size-sorting escape grids improved size-selection of haddock, but not of saithe or cod, compared to standard nets without grids.
[Statement 8]: Different designs and configurations of size-sorting grids show variable results.
[Statement 9]: Some studies found certain designs of size-sorting grids provided better size-selectivity for unwanted redfish, Greenland halibut, and commercial target hake compared to other designs.
[Statement 10]: Several studies found that the effects of size-sorting grids on size-selectivity varied between different fish species.
[Statement 11]: At least one study found that size-sorting grids resulted in no improvement in size-selectivity.
[Statement 12]: When combined with square mesh codends, size-sorting grids effectively reduced unwanted catches of whiting, plaice, cod, and haddock.
[Statement 13]: The combination of size-sorting grids and square mesh codends did not effectively reduce unwanted catches of hake.
[Statement 14]: Evidence shows large supported openings are primarily effective for reducing unwanted catch rather than improving size-selectivity.
[Statement 15]: Studies found that large supported escape openings, including Fisheyes, Bigeyes and radial escape sections, reduced overall catches of unwanted fish and immature red snapper compared to standard nets.
[Statement 16]: No specific size-selectivity improvements were reported in studies of large supported escape openings.
[Statement 17]: When large supported openings were combined with grids, studies found reduced catches of unwanted fish, sharks, and rays.
[Statement 18]: The combination of mesh escape panels with size-sorting grids appears more effective than using the individual devices alone.
[Statement 19]: Studies have shown that using both mesh escape panels and size-sorting grids together can reduce unwanted catch and improve size-selectivity.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__How do mesh escape panels, size-sorting grids, and large supported openings compare in their effectiveness at improving size-selectivity in trawl nets?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on the available evidence, there are limited direct comparative studies between prohibiting all static fishing gear versus prohibiting only line fishing.
[Statement 2]: One study in the Coral Sea, Australia, found that areas closed to non-towed fishing gears had higher overall shark abundance when sampled with longlines but not gillnets compared to areas where commercial gillnets were permitted.
[Statement 3]: The same study in the Coral Sea found that shark length was greater for two of five species or groups, similar for two, and dependent on sampling gear for one species in closed areas compared to areas where commercial gillnets were permitted.
[Statement 4]: A study in the Indian Ocean, South Africa, found that prohibiting offshore line fishing and all other boat-based fishing in a marine protected area zone resulted in higher abundances of four of four fish species over-exploited by line fishing.
[Statement 5]: These higher abundances were found when compared to two zones where boat-based line and spear fishing was permitted.
[Statement 6]: The same study in the Indian Ocean found that four of four fish species over-exploited by line fishing were larger in the protected zone which had been closed for two to seven years.
[Statement 7]: The evidence suggests that both prohibiting all static fishing gear and prohibiting only line fishing can increase fish abundance.
[Statement 8]: The studies on these different prohibition approaches examined different fish groups, such as sharks for static gear prohibition and line-targeted species for line fishing prohibition.
[Statement 9]: The studies also examined different geographic regions, making direct comparison difficult based on available data.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the comparative effects on fish abundance of prohibiting all static fishing gear versus prohibiting only line fishing?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Marine protected areas with zonation systems that permit some fishing show variable outcomes for fish populations depending on the level of restrictions in different zones.
[Statement 2]: In marine protected areas with zonation systems, fish abundance and biomass varied with the level of restriction between zones.
[Statement 3]: Non-fished zones (no-entry and no-take) showed higher density, biomass, and abundance of fish compared to fished zones inside areas protected for 10 to 27 years.
[Statement 4]: The effects of zonation systems on fish populations varied between fish feeding groups, zone protection level, and reef region.
[Statement 5]: Fish abundance and size were generally largest within no-take zones compared to partially fished zones within the same marine protected area system.
[Statement 6]: One study found a higher number of fish species in the no-fishing/no access zone of a multi-zoned marine protected area compared to two partially fished zones and unprotected fished areas 10 to 15 years after implementation.
[Statement 7]: Controlling human activity in marine protected areas with zonation systems resulted in larger average lengths of steentjies and three seabream species compared to unprotected fished areas.
[Statement 8]: The average lengths of steentjies and three seabream species were largest within a no-take zone compared to a partially fished zone.
[Statement 9]: Larger sizes were found for four of four studied coral reef fish species in zones where nearly all fishing is prohibited compared to adjacent zones with fewer fishing restrictions two to seven years after protection.
[Statement 10]: Most individuals of reef fish species tagged and released inside protected areas were recaptured again at almost the same locations over four to nine years.
[Statement 11]: The recaptured reef fish were mainly found in zones where all or nearly all fishing was prohibited, indicating increased protection from fishing.
[Statement 12]: One study found that restricting all fishing activity except for bait fishing in marine protected areas for seven years resulted in similar total fish biomass and lower total fish density compared to unprotected areas.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the outcomes for fish populations when marine protected areas are managed with zonation systems that permit some fishing?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The effectiveness of prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gear varies between regions, with studies from the North Atlantic, Mediterranean, and Indian Ocean showing different outcomes.
[Statement 2]: In the North Atlantic Ocean, studies on the prohibition of bottom trawling found mixed results.
[Statement 3]: One study in the North Atlantic Ocean showed increased total fish biomass after 15 years in areas closed to bottom trawling.
[Statement 4]: Another North Atlantic study found no effect on the abundance of bottom-dwelling fish species after 10 years of a bottom trawling closure.
[Statement 5]: North Atlantic studies showed no increases in haddock recruitment or survival seven years after a bottom trawling closure.
[Statement 6]: In the Mediterranean Sea, the effectiveness of closing areas to bottom-towed fishing gears appeared more positive.
[Statement 7]: Studies in the Mediterranean Sea showed higher biomass of adult red mullet after 14 years in areas closed to bottom-towed fishing gears.
[Statement 8]: Mediterranean studies also showed increased recruitment of young red mullet after 14 years when areas were closed to bottom-towed fishing gears.
[Statement 9]: The closure of fishing areas in the Mediterranean also led to increased adult red mullet sizes.
[Statement 10]: Mediterranean studies of bottom trawling prohibitions showed a different invertebrate community composition compared to trawled areas after 15-20 years.
[Statement 11]: The effect of bottom trawling prohibitions on invertebrate diversity in the Mediterranean had mixed results depending on the study duration.
[Statement 12]: In the Indian Ocean, results from prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gears varied significantly between studies and species.
[Statement 13]: One Indian Ocean study found an increased abundance of long-snouted seahorses, but not short-snouted seahorses, after one year of prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gears.
[Statement 14]: Another study in the Indian Ocean found that fish catch rates were higher in areas that had prohibited seine nets for 3-6 years.
[Statement 15]: Indian Ocean studies of complete commercial fishing bans showed larger overall fish sizes in marine reserves after five years compared to fished areas.
[Statement 16]: Evidence suggests that the effectiveness of mobile bottom fishing gear prohibitions may depend on regional factors, species studied, enforcement duration, and specific gear types prohibited.
[Statement 17]: Studies in the Mediterranean generally show more consistent positive outcomes from prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gear than studies in the North Atlantic or Indian Ocean.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__How does the effectiveness of prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gear vary between the North Atlantic and other regions like the Mediterranean or Indian Ocean?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Separator trawls have been examined in two studies and show specific effectiveness in reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 2]: One replicated, randomized study in the North Sea found that a separator trawl separated unwanted cod from target fish species into the lower codend.
[Statement 3]: The lower codend of the separator trawl had a larger mesh size which allowed more unwanted smaller cod to escape capture.
[Statement 4]: One replicated study in the Atlantic Ocean found that a separator trawl fitted with a square-mesh escape panel caught less of one of two unwanted fish species in a crustacean fishery.
[Statement 5]: Topless (coverless) trawls have been examined in four studies with variable results.
[Statement 6]: Two of four replicated, controlled studies found that using a topless trawl reduced the catch of unwanted Atlantic cod compared to conventional trawl types.
[Statement 7]: Two of four replicated, controlled studies found that using a topless trawl reduced discards of commercial fish species compared to conventional trawl types.
[Statement 8]: In one case, a topless trawl was used in combination with another non-conventional trawl type.
[Statement 9]: The four replicated, controlled studies on topless trawls took place in the North Sea, Gulf of Maine, and North Sea, Skagerrak and Baltic Sea.
[Statement 10]: One study found that topless trawls reduced unwanted catches of larger haddock but not smaller haddock compared to standard trawl types.
[Statement 11]: One study found that topless trawls reduced unwanted catches of larger Atlantic cod in only one of two cases, compared to standard trawl types.
[Statement 12]: Another study found that discarded catches of one of four commercial fish species were reduced in topless trawls.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__How do separator trawls and topless trawls compare in their effectiveness at reducing unwanted fish catch?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Twenty-three studies examined the effects of modifying fishing trap or pot configuration on marine fish populations across various global locations.
[Statement 2]: The studies on fishing trap modifications were conducted in locations including the Atlantic Ocean, Baltic Sea, Mediterranean Sea, Southern Ocean, Tasman Sea, Adriatic Sea, Bothnian Sea, Indian Ocean, Pacific Ocean, the Kattegat and the Barents Sea.
[Statement 3]: One study found that the survival of small herring that escaped from a pontoon fish trap through a size-sorting grid was similar to trap-caught herring that did not pass through a grid.
[Statement 4]: Sixteen of twenty studies found that modifications to trap configuration reduced unwanted catches of various fish species compared to unmodified conventional traps.
[Statement 5]: Modifications to trap configuration that reduced unwanted catches included using different trap types, increased mesh size, and fitting escape devices.
[Statement 6]: The fish species with reduced unwanted catches due to trap modifications include brown trout, black sea bass, herring, bluethroat wrasse and leatherjacket, cod, protected rockfishes, whitefish, American eel and winter flounder, and sharks/rays.
[Statement 7]: Three studies found that trap modification had no effect on unwanted catches of white croaker, non-commercial fish, or undersized Atlantic cod.
[Statement 8]: One study found that trap modifications increased non-target haddock catches.
[Statement 9]: Three of four studies found that traps or pots modified with square mesh escape windows or larger mesh sizes improved size-selectivity of Atlantic cod, black sea bass, and most fish species compared to smaller mesh and standard gear.
[Statement 10]: One study found that increasing the mesh size of trap escape panels had no effect on the size-selectivity of panga.
[Statement 11]: Trap modifications showed effects on marine mammals.
[Statement 12]: Using steel rods on lobster pots and metal frames on fishing pots reduced sea lion pup and seal entrapments.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the documented effects of modifying fishing trap or pot configurations on marine fish?
_claude-sonnet-4__What is the evidence for using electropositive deterrents on fishing gear to reduce unwanted catches of sharks and rays?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Nine studies examined the effect of attaching electropositive deterrents to fishing gear on marine fish populations.
[Statement 2]: The studies were conducted across the Atlantic Ocean, the Gulf of Alaska, the South Pacific Ocean, the Tasman Sea, and in laboratory facilities.
[Statement 3]: A global systematic review also examined the effect of electropositive deterrents on fishing gear.
[Statement 4]: Three of four replicated studies found that electropositive deterrent materials attached near bait reduced feeding attempts by spiny dogfish, great hammerhead, and draughtboard sharks compared to gear without deterrents.
[Statement 5]: Three of four replicated studies found that electropositive deterrent materials attached near bait reduced bait consumption by spiny dogfish, great hammerhead, and draughtboard sharks compared to gear without deterrents.
[Statement 6]: One study found no reduction in bait consumption by bonnethead and young lemon sharks when using electropositive deterrents.
[Statement 7]: One study found that the behavior of commercially valuable Pacific halibut was unaffected by deterrent materials.
[Statement 8]: Two of four replicated, controlled studies found that fishing gear fitted with electropositive deterrents caught fewer unwanted spiny dogfish, longnose skate, sharks, and rays compared to standard fishing gear.
[Statement 9]: The two studies also found that gear with electropositive deterrents caught fewer undersized halibut compared to standard fishing gear or gear with non-deterrent materials.
[Statement 10]: Two other studies found that electropositive deterrents resulted in similar catches of unwanted spiny dogfish, total shark catch, and blue shark compared to gear with no deterrents.
[Statement 11]: A global systematic review found that electropositive deterrents resulted in similar catches of unwanted spiny dogfish, total shark catch, blue shark, and total sharks and rays compared to gear with no deterrents.

[Statement 1]: In European waters, evidence from multiple studies shows that square mesh codends can be effective at reducing unwanted catch compared to diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 2]: The effectiveness of square mesh codends at reducing unwanted catch varies by species and location.
[Statement 3]: Studies in the English Channel found that square mesh codends caught less non-commercial unwanted invertebrates in one of two areas compared to diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 4]: In one of two areas studied in the English Channel, square mesh codends caught similar amounts of non-commercial unwanted invertebrates compared to diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 5]: In the Bristol Channel, one study found that the short-term survival of two of six fish species was higher after escaping through square mesh compared to diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 6]: Studies across European waters found that square mesh codends reduced unwanted catches of all monitored fish species.
[Statement 7]: Studies across European waters found that square mesh codends reduced unwanted catches of young individuals of most commercially targeted fish.
[Statement 8]: Some studies in European waters found that square mesh codends reduced the total unwanted catch.
[Statement 9]: Four studies found no reduction in catches of unwanted small rockfish and flatfish when using square mesh codends.
[Statement 10]: Some studies found no reduction in the total unwanted catch when using square mesh codends.
[Statement 11]: In the North Sea, studies found that trawl nets with escape grids and square mesh codends caught fewer unwanted whiting, plaice, cod, and haddock compared to diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 12]: Studies in the Adriatic Sea, Aegean Sea, English Channel, Mediterranean Sea, and the Kattegat and Skagerrak found that square mesh codends improved size selectivity for several species including European hake, horse mackerel, poor cod, greater forkbeard, and blue whiting.
[Statement 13]: Five studies found no difference in size selectivity for other species like Atlantic mackerel and long rough dab when using square mesh codends.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__In European waters, what does the evidence show about the effectiveness of using a square mesh codend instead of a diamond mesh codend for reducing unwanted catch?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Seven site comparison studies in the Mediterranean Sea, Indian Ocean, Philippine Sea and Atlantic Ocean found that protected areas where all fishing had been prohibited for between three and 16 years had a different fish community composition compared to fished areas.
[Statement 2]: Three before-and-after studies in the Tasman Sea and South China Sea found that fish assemblage/species composition was different before and after prohibiting all commercial fishing.
[Statement 3]: Fourteen of 20 site comparison studies found that marine protected areas that had prohibited all fishing for between one to more than 25 years had higher fish species richness compared to fished areas.
[Statement 4]: Six studies found similar fish species richness between one and 20 years after all fishing was banned in protected areas compared to fished areas.
[Statement 5]: One systematic review in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans found no difference in species richness between unfished protected areas and fished areas.
[Statement 6]: One replicated site comparison study in the Indian Ocean found that the effects of prohibiting all fishing on fish species richness/diversity after 15 years varied with the sampling method used.
[Statement 7]: One site comparison study in the Caribbean Sea found that in marine protected areas closed to all fishing with limited exceptions for up to seven years, there was lower total fish species richness compared to unprotected areas.
[Statement 8]: One before-and-after study in the South China Sea found that fish species richness decreased in the wider region five years after all commercial fishing was banned in two marine reserves.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the documented benefits of ceasing all fishing in a marine protected area on fish community composition and species richness?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Both square mesh codends and rotating diamond mesh codends can improve size-selectivity in trawl nets.
[Statement 2]: Square mesh codends and rotating diamond mesh codends show different effectiveness patterns for improving size-selectivity.
[Statement 3]: Square mesh codends improved size selectivity for silver hake, horse mackerel, and European hake compared to diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 4]: Square mesh codends improved size selectivity for axillary seabream, poor cod, and greater forkbeard compared to diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 5]: Square mesh codends improved size selectivity for blue whiting and discarded fish compared to diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 6]: Square mesh codends improved size selectivity for three of four commercially targeted fish compared to diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 7]: Some studies found no difference in size selectivity between square and diamond mesh codends for Atlantic mackerel and long rough dab.
[Statement 8]: Some studies found no difference in size selectivity between square and diamond mesh codends for yellowtail scad, striped seapike, rockfish, and flatfish.
[Statement 9]: Some studies found no difference in size selectivity between square and diamond mesh codends for three of four commercially important bottom fish species.
[Statement 10]: The effect of square mesh codends on selectivity varied with fish body shape.
[Statement 11]: With square mesh codends, round-bodied fish showed improved selectivity, but flatfish did not.
[Statement 12]: Turning diamond mesh orientation by 90° resulted in better size selection of cod, red mullet, and common pandora compared to standard orientation diamond mesh.
[Statement 13]: Turning diamond mesh orientation by 90° resulted in better size selection of round-bodied fish species compared to standard orientation diamond mesh.
[Statement 14]: Turning diamond mesh orientation by 90° did not result in better size selection of plaice, annular sea bream, and flatfish species compared to standard orientation diamond mesh.
[Statement 15]: One study found that turning the mesh did not improve size selectivity of cod, plaice, and flounder.
[Statement 16]: Square mesh codends reduced unwanted catches of all monitored fish species compared to diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 17]: Square mesh codends reduced unwanted catches of young individuals of half or most commercially targeted fish compared to diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 18]: Square mesh codends reduced the total unwanted catch compared to diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 19]: Square mesh codends reduced unwanted catches of discarded fish in deeper fishing areas compared to diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 20]: Fish caught in square mesh codends had higher short-term survival rates for two of six fish species compared to fish caught in diamond mesh codends.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__How does using a square mesh codend compare to rotating a diamond mesh codend for improving size-selectivity in trawl nets?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: There are notable differences in the effects of prohibiting all commercial fishing on fish community composition between the Tasman Sea and the South Atlantic Ocean.
[Statement 2]: In the Tasman Sea, two before-and-after studies found that fish assemblage and species composition was different before and after prohibiting all commercial fishing.
[Statement 3]: Changes in fish composition were observed in a Tasman Sea estuary after two years of prohibiting all commercial fishing.
[Statement 4]: Changes in fish composition were observed in the wider region surrounding two marine reserves in the Tasman Sea five years after the creation of the reserves.
[Statement 5]: One before-and-after study in the Tasman Sea found that most fish species in an estuary in a marine reserve had lower abundance two years after the estuary was closed to all commercial fishing than before.
[Statement 6]: One site comparison study in the South Atlantic Ocean found no change in species composition between a reserve closed to all commercial fishing for 40 years and unprotected fished areas.
[Statement 7]: A study in the South Atlantic Ocean found no difference in overall fish diversity between a protected area closed to all commercial fishing for 40 years compared to unprotected fished areas.
[Statement 8]: A study in the South Atlantic Ocean found that there were higher abundances of one of four commercially targeted fish species in a protected area compared to unprotected fished areas.
[Statement 9]: Studies in the Tasman Sea documented changes in community composition following fishing prohibition.
[Statement 10]: A study in the South Atlantic Ocean found no change in community composition despite 40 years of protection.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__How do the effects on fish community composition of prohibiting all commercial fishing compare between the Tasman Sea and the South Atlantic Ocean?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence suggests variable timeframes for fish abundance to increase following fishing prohibitions in marine protected areas.
[Statement 2]: Marine protected areas prohibiting all fishing for 1 to 25 years or more showed higher fish abundances compared to fished areas.
[Statement 3]: 30 of 54 studies found positive effects on fish abundance from marine protected areas that prohibit all fishing.
[Statement 4]: Some studies found similar fish abundances between protected and fished areas between 1 and 20 years after implementation of the protected areas.
[Statement 5]: Restricting all fishing activity in marine protected areas for 1 to 8 years resulted in similar fish abundance and biomass compared to unprotected areas.
[Statement 6]: One study showed lower total fish density after a marine protected area was in place for 7 years.
[Statement 7]: The effects of fishing prohibitions on abundance varied between different fish species and groups.
[Statement 8]: Some studies showed that the effects on fish abundance depended on the age of the protected area.
[Statement 9]: One review found that fish abundance in no-take marine reserves that were 1 to 25 years old was affected by the duration of protection among other factors.
[Statement 10]: In zonation systems, fish abundance and biomass increased after 3-15 years compared to unprotected areas.
[Statement 11]: Studies on the effects of fishing closures on fish abundance have found mixed results.
[Statement 12]: Some protected areas showed higher fish abundances after 5 years and 40 years of being closed to fishing.
[Statement 13]: Other protected areas showed no increase in fish abundance 2 to 13 years after closure.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What does the evidence suggest about the timeframe over which prohibiting all fishing in a marine protected area leads to increased fish abundance?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: According to global reviews, catch share systems show evidence of effectiveness for sustainable fish stock management.
[Statement 2]: Two worldwide systematic reviews examined the effects of introducing catch shares on marine fish populations.
[Statement 3]: One review found that fisheries or stocks managed under catch shares were more likely to meet management target levels for biomass sustainability than fisheries or stocks that did not meet targets.
[Statement 4]: Another study found no difference in performance of biomass-based management targets between fisheries under catch shares, fleet-wide catch caps or fishing effort controls.
[Statement 5]: Two worldwide systematic reviews found that catch share fisheries had lower rates of over-exploitation compared to non-catch share fisheries.
[Statement 6]: A higher proportion of fisheries managed under catch shares either met or exceeded management target levels for rates of exploitation than fisheries that did not meet targets.
[Statement 7]: One global systematic review comparing different management approaches found that catch share fisheries performed similarly to fleet-wide catch quotas in terms of reaching biomass-based management targets.
[Statement 8]: Along with catch quota fisheries, fewer catch share stocks were over-exploited than stocks with effort controls.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the evidence from global reviews on the effectiveness of catch share systems for managing fish stocks sustainably?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: There are notable differences between the effects of long-term versus temporary fishery closures on marine fish populations.
[Statement 2]: Five studies found limited positive effects of temporary fishery closures.
[Statement 3]: One study in the Atlantic Ocean found no increase in cod spawning stock biomass over nine years in temporarily closed areas compared to fished areas.
[Statement 4]: One study in the Atlantic Ocean found no change in cod survival over nine years in temporarily closed areas compared to fished areas.
[Statement 5]: One study in the Atlantic Ocean found no change in cod length composition over nine years in temporarily closed areas compared to fished areas.
[Statement 6]: Tagged adult cod spent nearly a third of their time inside seasonally closed spawning areas.
[Statement 7]: Seasonally closed spawning areas provided increased protection for adult cod from bottom-dwelling fish gear during spawning periods.
[Statement 8]: Studies on temporary fishery closures showed mixed results on commercial catch.
[Statement 9]: Some fish groups showed increased catch rates during temporary closures while other fish groups showed no change.
[Statement 10]: Five studies examining long-term fishery closures showed more consistent positive effects.
[Statement 11]: Studies found a higher abundance of young salmon returning to rivers five years after a long-term closure.
[Statement 12]: The effects of long-term fishery closures on salmon abundance varied by species.
[Statement 13]: Fish in long-term closed areas showed reduced flight response distances, making the fish more vulnerable to capture.
[Statement 14]: Long-term fishery closures resulted in reduced overall fishing effort.
[Statement 15]: Long-term fishery closures resulted in varied annual catch rates.
[Statement 16]: The effects of long-term fishery closures were mixed, with some studies finding lower abundance of certain species like monkfish in closed areas.
[Statement 17]: The most comprehensive evidence on fishery closures comes from 79 studies on complete fishing prohibitions in marine protected areas.
[Statement 18]: Areas prohibiting all fishing for one to 27 years showed higher fish abundances compared to fished areas.
[Statement 19]: Areas prohibiting all fishing for one to 27 years showed larger fish sizes compared to fished areas.
[Statement 20]: Areas prohibiting all fishing for one to 27 years showed higher species richness compared to fished areas.
[Statement 21]: Areas prohibiting all fishing for one to 27 years showed a different community composition compared to fished areas.
[Statement 22]: The effects of complete fishing prohibitions varied between species.
[Statement 23]: Some species showed similar abundances between protected areas and fished areas.
[Statement 24]: The duration of protection influenced the effectiveness of complete fishing prohibitions.
[Statement 25]: Longer protection periods generally showed stronger positive effects.
[Statement 26]: Evidence suggests that complete, long-term fishing prohibitions are more effective than temporary closures.
[Statement 27]: While temporary closures provide some protection during critical periods like spawning, temporary closures show limited population-level benefits.
[Statement 28]: Long-term closures and complete fishing prohibitions demonstrate more substantial and consistent positive effects on fish abundance, size, and community structure.
[Statement 29]: The magnitude of effects from long-term closures and complete prohibitions varies among species.
[Statement 30]: The magnitude of effects from long-term closures and complete prohibitions depends on factors such as enforcement, habitat type, and the level of fishing pressure in adjacent areas.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the comparative effects of long-term versus temporary fishery closures on marine fish populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Electropositive deterrents attached to fishing gear showed mixed results for reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 2]: Fishing gear, such as longlines and traps, fitted with electropositive deterrent materials caught fewer unwanted spiny dogfish, longnose skate, sharks, rays, and undersized halibut compared to standard fishing gear.
[Statement 3]: Electropositive deterrents resulted in catches of unwanted spiny dogfish, sharks, and blue shark that were similar to gear with no deterrents.
[Statement 4]: Electropositive materials reduced the frequency of feeding attempts and bait consumption by spiny dogfish, great hammerhead, and draughtboard sharks.
[Statement 5]: Electropositive materials did not reduce bait consumption by bonnethead and young lemon sharks.
[Statement 6]: Artificial lights on fishing gear demonstrated more consistent positive effects.
[Statement 7]: Shrimp trawl nets with artificial lights caught fewer unwanted fish when the lights were fitted to the fishing line.
[Statement 8]: Shrimp trawl nets with artificial lights did not catch fewer unwanted fish when the lights were fitted to a size-sorting grid.
[Statement 9]: Gillnets with LED lights, light sticks, or UV lights caught fewer green turtles and loggerhead turtles than nets without lights.
[Statement 10]: In the Adriatic Sea, no loggerhead turtles were caught and died in gillnets equipped with UV lights.
[Statement 11]: In the Adriatic Sea, some loggerhead turtles were caught and died in nets without lights.
[Statement 12]: Increasing the number of light sticks on longlines had mixed effects on the chance of catching loggerhead and leatherback turtles.
[Statement 13]: Visual deterrents showed limited effectiveness.
[Statement 14]: Gillnets with floating shark shapes attached caught fewer green turtles than unmodified nets.
[Statement 15]: Shark-shaped and spherical deterrents had mixed effects on loggerhead turtle behaviors.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the observed effects of fitting deterrents, such as lights or electropositive materials, to fishing gear?
_claude-sonnet-4__What are the most effective spatial management actions for protecting spawning fish and their habitats?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several spatial management approaches have been evaluated for protecting spawning fish and their habitats.
[Statement 2]: Marine Protected Areas with complete fishing prohibitions show the most comprehensive benefits.
[Statement 3]: Ceasing or prohibiting all types of fishing in marine protected areas resulted in higher fish abundances, larger fish sizes, different community composition, and higher species richness/diversity.
[Statement 4]: Marine protected areas with complete fishing prohibitions provided protection for commercially important reef fish species and shark species for large proportions of time.
[Statement 5]: Marine protected areas with complete fishing prohibitions effectively protected commercially important reef fish and shark species from fishing pressure.
[Statement 6]: Temporary and seasonal fishery closures provide targeted protection during critical spawning periods.
[Statement 7]: Spawning and nursery areas closed seasonally or permanently to fishing were used by tagged adult Atlantic cod for nearly a third of the time during spawning.
[Statement 8]: Spawning and nursery areas closed seasonally or permanently to fishing were used by young school sharks for up to 80% of the time.
[Statement 9]: Tagged adult cod spent nearly a third of their time inside seasonally closed cod spawning areas during the closure's implementation.
[Statement 10]: Seasonally closed cod spawning areas provided increased protection from bottom-dwelling fish gears during spawning periods.
[Statement 11]: Long-term fishery closures demonstrate varied effectiveness.
[Statement 12]: Areas closed to groundfish fisheries for six to eight years showed a higher abundance of some fish species.
[Statement 13]: Areas closed to customary fishing for eight years resulted in fish having lower flight response distances, making the fish less wary of capture.
[Statement 14]: Periodic fishing restrictions offer a balanced approach.
[Statement 15]: Protected areas fished only for short periods over 18 months to six years had greater fish biomass than openly fished areas.
[Statement 16]: Protected areas fished only for short periods had similar biomass to areas permanently closed to fishing for six years.
[Statement 17]: Habitat protection measures supplement fishing restrictions.
[Statement 18]: Marine protected areas prohibiting dredging for approximately 2.5 years had different invertebrate and fish community composition compared to unprotected dredged sites.
[Statement 19]: Marine protected areas prohibiting dredging for approximately 2.5 years had a greater cover of habitat-forming species compared to unprotected dredged sites.
[Statement 20]: Areas where fishing gears targeting bottom-dwelling species had been prohibited for 15 years had higher numbers of larger and older cod than openly fished areas.

[Statement 1]: Both Mediterranean Sea and Indian Ocean marine protected areas show positive effects on fish communities when all fishing is prohibited.
[Statement 2]: Specific regional comparisons of the effects of marine protected areas on fish communities between the Mediterranean Sea and the Indian Ocean are limited.
[Statement 3]: In the Mediterranean Sea, studies examining areas that prohibited all fishing for 3-16 years found a different fish community composition compared to fished areas.
[Statement 4]: Mediterranean no-take areas showed higher fish species richness and diversity in some cases.
[Statement 5]: 14 of 20 studies across multiple ocean regions, including the Mediterranean, found higher fish species richness in protected areas compared to fished areas after 1-25+ years of protection.
[Statement 6]: Fish abundance studies showed that Mediterranean protected areas had higher abundances of targeted and non-targeted fish species.
[Statement 7]: In Mediterranean protected areas, the effects on fish abundance varied between individual species groups based on the species' commercial status and position in the food chain.
[Statement 8]: Fish sizes were larger in Mediterranean no-take areas.
[Statement 9]: 8 of 11 studies across multiple regions, including the Mediterranean, found larger fish in protected areas after 1-22 years compared to fished areas.
[Statement 10]: One Mediterranean study found greater reproductive success, with more eggs of four commercially targeted fish species in a 3-year-old reserve compared to fished areas.
[Statement 11]: In the Indian Ocean, 15 studies that examined the effects of prohibiting all fishing observed similar positive patterns.
[Statement 12]: Indian Ocean protected areas showed a different fish community composition compared to fished areas after 3-16 years of protection.
[Statement 13]: Fish species richness and diversity were higher in Indian Ocean no-take areas in the majority of studies, following the same pattern as Mediterranean areas.
[Statement 14]: Fish abundance was higher in Indian Ocean protected areas.
[Statement 15]: 30 of 54 studies across all regions, including the Indian Ocean, found higher fish abundances in no-take areas after up to 25+ years of protection.
[Statement 16]: Fish grazing rates were higher in Indian Ocean protected areas compared to fished areas.
[Statement 17]: Both the Mediterranean Sea and Indian Ocean regions show positive responses to no-take protection.
[Statement 18]: The specific magnitude and timing of the effects of no-take protection may vary based on local conditions, enforcement, and the particular fish species present.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__How does the effectiveness of no-take marine protected areas on fish communities differ between the Mediterranean Sea and the Indian Ocean?
